name: Recreation of Molnar's (Des) Ordres
description: A recreation of one of Molnar's pioneer algorithmic art, (Des) Ordres (1974), portraying the balance between chaos and structure, and implementing randomness in everything from the stroke to the square's angles to achieve that.

name: Variation of (Des) Ordres
description: This recreation achieves a more visually engaging result by implementing randomness in color, and adding depth by drawing layers on top of each other.

name: Second variation of (Des) Ordres
description: This second variation takes it a step further by adopting motion and a pulsating effect, aiming for a more dynamic feel while keeping coherence throguh the use of a specific color palette.

name: Noise
description: An interpretation of perlin noise aiming to create depth in a pattern using simple nested for loops

name: Ocean simulation
description: I tried combining code with nature to recreate earths landscapes, in this case recreating the ocean by drawing two layers of grids and playing with their opacity to create depth and resonant motion.

name: Flow Gradient
description: This experiment is a layered flowing grid of many colorful ellipses, it simulates liquid or abstract patterns.

name: Perlin Flow Field
description: This generative artwork is inspired by Daniel Shiffman, it simulates thousands of particles that flow through the field and, again are driven by perlin noise. Each particle follows a vector creating continuous and smooth evolution of paths. I wanted to try to simulate the drawing of a pencil on a blank canvas.

name: Colored Flow Field
description: While this piece follows a very similar structure to the previous Flow Field, this one differs in randomized motion, layered trajectories, and evolution of color, aiming to simulate natural movements found in earths landscapes.

name: Triangle Flow Field
description: This experiment lets triangles flow along the field, shifting through different hues creating a visually pleasing motion.

name: Sound Circles
description: A playful experiment combining sound and visuals illustrating bubbles for each note played.
